Award.AwardTitle: Building and Sustaining an International Digital Government Research Community of Practice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT
NSF-0540069

Dawes, Sharon

Over the past decade, growing evidence demonstrates that "digital government" (DG) is developing as a global field of inquiry. Because of the relative newness of the DG field, there is insufficient interaction among researchers in different countries compared to what one finds in more established scientific disciplines. Most funded research around the world addresses DG challenges within the context of a single country; only a few investigations have compared results across national boundaries or tackled problems that are transnational in scope. The result of this situation is that comparative and transnational issues in DG, which are of growing importance in an increasingly networked world, are not receiving the attention they deserve. To address this gap, the team will plan, develop, and implement a four-year strategy to create opportunities and venues for international research discussions and to enable U.S. researchers and educators to advance their work through international collaboration. A small international advisory group will be named to help guide the work, connect to research sponsors in other countries, and periodically assess progress toward goals.

The proposed activities will document the development and current state of digital government research and foster relationships and intellectual engagements that will enrich it as a domain of inquiry throughout the world. The results will contribute to innovative research questions and methods, identify gaps in current knowledge that could be the focus of future research, and constitute a useful guide to individual researchers who are interested in forming relationships with international investigators who share their interests. All of these effects create an arena where research problems amenable to international treatment can be identified and investigated. This set of activities would benefit the NSF research community as well as those in other countries by building and sustaining relationships among both researchers and research sponsors around the world in an effort to catalog, compare, and where possible build synergies among funding decisions about digital government research. This project will contribute directly to the ability of US researchers and graduate students to work successfully, and in a sustained way, in international settings. The proposed international summer institute will help to train future generations of digital government scientists.

Building On-ramps to International Research Collaboration: Replicable strategies for entry, productivity and sustainability

 

Globalization presents important opportunities and difficult challenges that demand researchers who can collaborate on topics that cross borders, political systems, and cultures. International research collaborations on topics such as livability of cities or regulation of world financial markets offer great benefit, but it is usually logistically and financially impractical. Existing approaches tend to be formal and expensive, focused on parallel rather than integrated projects, and stymied by uncoordinated requirements of multiple funders. In response to this problem, we experimented with two low-cost innovative approaches to international research collaboration in our multi-disciplinary field of digital government. The first was a set of competitively selected international working groups, the second a residential research institute for doctoral students.

 

 The working group strategy had three aims: to encourage interest in international research topics, to do so through self-organizing teams of scholars from different countries, and to support these teams with a very limited package of incentives and requirements. Each of three groups worked for three years on its chosen topic (ICT support for public governance, North American cooperation, and early crisis detection). They were required to have US and non-US co-chairs, include senior and junior members, hold periodic face to face meetings, and give public reports of their progress. Each group received about $70,000 in travel funds for participants from US institutions, but no funding was provided for salaries or research costs. Non-US participants covered all their own expenses.

 

By contrast to the working groups in which the same people met repeatedly, the doctoral institutes were an immersive experience in international engagement for four successive cohorts of students. The goals of the iGov Research Institute were to create long-lasting social and intellectual ties among the participants, to simulate the challenges and benefits of multi-disciplinary international research, and to emphasize the importance of social, political, and cultural context. Each week-long institute was held in a different city and involved a host institution and local government willing to participate actively in the program. Academic sessions led by senior faculty laid the groundwork for integrative small group projects supported by junior faculty mentors. In all 75 students from more than 20 countries participated at an average operating cost of $4000 per student.

 

We evaluated both experiments using surveys, observations, and interviews.

 

Each working group accomplished substantive results in its chosen area including a multi-authored book on citizen consultation, several successful international grant proposals, and direct impact on watershed management in India. They also produced conference and journal papers, case studies, and software and reported hundreds of instances of collaborative scholarly work including articles, dissertation committees, and conference panels. Contrary to common belief, online collaboration tools contributed little to relationship building and group productivity. We also identified effective and readily replicable practices to optimize face-to-face time, remain open and flexible about goals and strategies for reaching them, recognize effects on different career stages, and support multiple forms of leadership.
